Class Game

  • java.lang.Object
    • Game

  • public class Game
extends java.lang.Object
    This is the class that will execute our game. Add yourself as author in Javadoc for the extra methods you write. You are expected to write many of your own methods. In general, it is good to keep methods short so that you can read the entire method code in one screen.

      Game()

      • Game

        public Game()

    • Method Detail

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
        This is where our game program starts execution.
        Parameters:
        args - The usual command line arguments array.

      • pause

        public static void pause()
        A prompt for the player so they have some time to read output.

      • getUserInput

        public static java.lang.String getUserInput(java.lang.String msg)
        Prints a prompt to the user for some String input, and then waits for the user to enter one line of text.
        Parameters:
        msg - The prompt for the user to read, so the player knows what kind of input to type.
        Returns:
        The line of text the user entered.

      • getUserChoice

        public static int getUserChoice(java.lang.String msg)
        Prints a prompt to the user for an integer input, and then waits for the user to enter an integer.
        Parameters:
        msg - The prompt for the user to read, so the player knows what integer values they can choose.
        Returns:
        The integer the user entered.

      • gameLoop

        public static void gameLoop()
        The basic program flow-of-control for our game. Most of your code here should be calling the other methods that you write. You are expected to write many of your own methods to keep your code organized.

      • promptForPlayerChoice

        public static void promptForPlayerChoice()
        This prints the prompt for the first choice the player has in the game: which kind of person will they play?

      • checkUserChoice

        public static boolean checkUserChoice(int choice,
                                      java.lang.String name)
        This validates the player's choice for which type of person they want to play as. The user could have entered an invalid choice, so we have to check that it is one of the available choices that are programmed in our game.
        Parameters:
        choice - The input integer the user entered.
        name - The player's name for inside the game.
        Returns:
        Will return true if the user's choice is valid, and false otherwise.

      • welcome

        public static void welcome()
        The start of the game. Any part of the game that should be set up before the play loop.

      • play

        public static boolean play()
        This method is the part of the game that can be repeated. The basic idea is to give the player a choice, and then process that choice towards some kind of goal. Attacking monsters is a very common theme in many games.
        Returns:
        Should return true to continue play, and false to end the game.

      • finish

        public static void finish()
        You should put any code here you want to be the last thing to execute.
